title: meghan markle not pitchforked off uk
story: It follows the fortunes, or rather, misfortunes, of Americans who fall in love with foreigners and have just over three months to get married or send them home.A massive leap of faith, it’s usually a matter of days — sometimes hours — before the clash of cultures, personalities, values and expectations make this the television gt that keeps on giving.Perhaps Meghan and Harry should sign up for season eight. For how much did they really know about each other before walking down the aisle Prince William apparently advised his more impetuous brother to wait so he could really get to know his American bride first, but Harry took umbrage and didn’t listen.Perhapshe had, he might have worked out in advance that an independent spirit joining such a restrictive institution wasn’t going to end well.Instead, they leapt before they looked and, with the “-month bride” having packed her bags already, have saddled the -year-old Queen with yet another constitutional crisis.Back in , I wrote a piece defending Meghan after she was criticised by old school friend Ninaki Priddy for being “calculated in the way she handled people and relationships” and a “curator of a beautul le”.But following the lavish baby shower, the jet-setting with A-listers and the swt jettisoning of inconveniently outspoken family members, the latter sentiment now rings true.And, of course, becoming a member of the most famous royal family in the world was the cherry on the top of that beautul le.But Meghan soon discovered it was nothing like the membership of her beloved Soho House.The rooms are draughty, the decor chintzy and, instead of reading the morning papers in your cashmere loungewear, you have to rise early, put on a frock and make your way to some rain-lashed outpost to open the new wing of a community centre where “live your best le” sentiments, however well-meaning, aren’t required.Here’s what is required as a member of the British Royal Family: Turn up on time, shake hands, smile, say little more than “have you come far ” Repeat.Not because the royals don’t have anything to say. They do, and air their views in private.But in public, their job is to shine a light on whatever project they’re visiting, not themselves. To show — via action, not virtue-signalling statements — a strong sense of duty.And inthey get to keep their ious mansions, hundreds of staff, personal bodyguards etc without any whf of civil unrest.That’s the deal.But those still in Meghan’s social circle glowingly describe her as organised, focused, and opinionated — very much an independent woman used to having her voice heard.As Prince Harry told courtiers just before their wedding: “What Meghan wants, Meghan gets.”An admirable quality when it comes to breaking through the glass ceiling of corporate le or securing the best table in the best restaurant, perhaps.But the monarchy is an institution steeped in hundreds of years of tradition, and Meghan — who claimed she “didn’t know much” about Harry when they first met — clearly thought she’d mould it to her way of thinking . . . then rapidly discovered that it ain’t for turning.Not that The Queen didn’t try very hard to accommodate the wants and needs of the newly anointed Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Contrary to royal tradition, they were permitted to keep the christening of baby Archie as a private affair and, despite there being a perfectly nice home at Kensington Palace they could have used, a publicly funded, £.million renovation of Frogmore Cottage was authorised.A “cottage” I might add, that used to be five homes but has now been knocked in to one because they managed to dodge the usual ban that prevents such moves because of the UK’s housing crisis.Shortly after, Prince Charles launched his blueprint to try to solve the dilemma faced by millions of young people struggling to find a home of their own. Oh the irony. And after all that, they now want to use it part-time as they flit back and forth across the Atlantic.Meghan is feeling disillusioned and homesick. We get it, and sympathise.But let’s not pretend, as some claim, that she’s been practically pitchforked off this island by racist bigots.This is not a racist country and, besides, the British public initially greeted her engagement and later marriage to Harry with unbridled joy.We love Harry. He’s a thoroughly decent person and deserves particular praise for the work he’s done with the Armed Forces, both while serving and afterwards.No, the disconnect has come from the fact that Meghan is still a Hollywood celebrity at heart and, consequently, never truly settled in her often boring and restrictive new role.She misses the relative freedom of her old le, not to mention her family and friends.Again, we get it. But was it really necessary to flee these shores asescaping for her le Clearly besotted with her, Harry faces the stark decision of giving her what she wants or losing her for ever. Or perhaps he’s genuinely sick of royal le and wants out too.If so, let’s wave goodbye and wish them luck.But. The have-cake-and-eat-it plan to stop being a “senior royal” and just dip in and out of duties that suit them simply isn’t going to work.SussexRoyal — which Harry and Meghan have registered as an official trademark for everything from “emotional support services” to clothing and magazines — is a title and privilege that comes with duties and conditions attached, not a brand, be it charitable or otherwise.The future of the monarchy depends on the goodwill, support and interest level of the public, and a recent survey showed that, while the majority have no issue with their decision to go, they were strongly against any continued taxpayer funding of their lavish lestyle.So— as early indicators go — The Queen allows Harry and Meghan to call the shots while keeping their royal titles, their taxpayer-funded security and an allowance from the Duchy of Cornwall, then one suspects this will be discussed by students for centuries to come as the turning point at which the British monarchy began its steady decline to irrelevance and, ultimately, abolition.MOVIE mega-star Will Smith popped in to the retirement party of a woman he last met  years ago.Anita Scipio was the receptionist at a US radio station when Will arrived for one of his first interviews as a young actor and he’s never forgotten how nice she was to him.“My favorite moments on the road are the ones where I can connect with people like @anitascipio,” -year-old Will told his Instagram followers before he walked in to the station to give her a hug.In the days before social media, someone who worked at his record company Sony told me that whenever he was in town, Will would tour the building, from post room to boardroom, giving time to everyone.He’s that rare creature, a star on screen and off.Some of today’s petulant slebs should watch and learn.FORMER psychiatric nurse Susan Evans is launching a landmark legal case to challenge consent issues around the provision of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones for under-s.She argues that children should be protected from “experimental” and “invasive medical treatment”, not least because “some children are referred despite having autism, being homosexual or suffering some form of trauma or sexual abuse”.Speaking on Radio , she added that children as young as nine were being asked to consent “to a completely experimental treatment for which long-term consequences are not known”.But gender ersity advocates warn that “a loss to trans youth is a loss to all”.Time will tell the outcome of her case but, meanwhile, in unrelated comments, I note that the actor Rupert Everett says he spent most of his early childhood wanting “to be a girl”.He adored his mother, aunt and grandmother, didn’t like men, and adds: “I loved necklaces and bras and all those kinds of things.”Then, when he reached , he “didn’t want to be a girl any more. I really enjoyed being a homosexual”.The case in point, perhaps, for treading very carefully indeed with pre-teens.POLICE officers will be required to have degrees from this year – a move that could remove , recruits from the front line while they complete their studies.Sigh. Really When it comes to tackling crime on our streets, the majority of us want someone on our side who possesses instinct, courage and common sense.Which you either have or don’t regardless of qualications.NATURISTS John and Donna Price have moved from Kent to Lincolnshire for more privacy because they like to barbecue in the nude.“I love a flambeed banana,” says Donna, .Oooer.Aren’t our AEs under enough pressure Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark huawei 5g network
story: This is a company that has brought us the technology of an iPhone but at a fraction of the cost.I am no protectionist and I don’t fear the Chinese.When it comes to selling us consumer goods, I am more than happy to welcome China’s companies into the country to compete with British, European or US-made products.But it is a very dferent matter when it comes to allowing a Chinese company to build Britain’s next- generation broadband network — with all the security issues that raises.Unbelievably, the Government is seriously considering doing just this.Yesterday, the Prime Minister — who is due to make a decision next month on whether to award Huawei a contract to build parts of Britain’s G network — indicated that he is inclined to give the company the nod.Critics, he said, needed to suggest which other company ought to be allowed to do the work.I am sorryI am a little ignorant on this point. While I have bought several mobile phones, I have never gone shopping for an entire telecoms network.But surely there must be other potential contractors. Don’t we have a telecoms industry of our own It doesn’t say much for the Government’s privatisation of BTit is not in the running for this sort of work.What about our own Vodafone, which I thought was one of the world leaders in mobile phone technology Evendepriving Huawei of the work meant we had to wait a little longer or pay a little extra to download a movie to our phones, that would surely be a reasonable price to pay for protecting national security.And national security policy really is at stake.Yesterday the US reaffirmed that allowing Huawei to build our G network — even parts of it which are deemed to be low- risk — would be “madness” and could compromise the willingness of the US to share vital intelligence with Britain in future.This didn’t come in one of Donald Trump’s notorious am tweets but from officials working for Matt Pottinger, the US deputy national security adviser, and Robert Blair, special representative for international telecommunications policy.That they took the trouble to visit London to warn of the dangers we could be getting ourselves into ought to be seen as a red flag on Huawei’s involvement in our G network.Surely, the importance of being able to share intelligence with our most important ally should rank above pure considerations of cost.Australia has already blocked the Chinese firm from its G network.Yet here, the head of MI Sir Andrew Parker said he had “no reason” to think Britain’s intelligence partnership with the US would sufferinvolvement from the Chinese firm was given the green light.But Defence Secretary Ben Wallace underlined at the weekend that the US administration has threatened to cut off some intelligenceBritain approves Huawei’s involvement in G.He said: “Those things will be taken into account when the Government collectively decides to make a decision on it.”Our own Government — as it has been doing since Theresa May’s day — insists that only parts of the G contract would be awarded to Huawei.It would not be allowed to work on security-critical areas.But that isn’t good enough. Such is the complexity of modern telecommunications networks that it would be impossible to be sure that systems installed in one part of the network were not enabling data to be obtained from another.Whoever designs and builds a telecommunications system gains the power to interfere with it, or even switch it off, should it feel inclined.Of course, with modern communications a huge amount of damage can be done from afar.Evenwe are confident our broadband network is secure now, we can’t be certain that would remain the case.A company which installs a telecommunications network will necessarily continue to be involved in maintaining and upgrading the network it had designed and installed.We have to be absolutely sure the network is not being used for some underhand purpose.Huawei denies that it is controlled by the Chinese state, and has threatened to sue commentators in France whom it alleges have made that claim.But the precise relationship between Huawei and the Chinese state is hardly the point.What is certain is that China is not a democracy and there is always going to be a security issue when it comes to involving its industrial giants in sensitive work here.We would not allow a Chinese company, say, to build fighter jets for the RAF or to construct our radar defence system.This kind of work is rightly the preserve of contractors on whom we can rely totally, even in times of international conflict.Such is the importance of telecommunications in military and civil defence that we now have to think of mobile networks in the same light.The Government has been warning for years that cyber warfare is the big coming threat.In  it published a Strategic Defence Review which defined cyber attack as a “Tier One” threat alongside terrorism.Last November, the US and Taiwanese held a joint exercise in fending off a major cyber attack on Taiwan.At the time the Taiwanese Cyber Security Agency said it was the subject of an astonishing million cyber attacks every month, half of which came from the Chinese mainland.So why, then, is our own Government even considering commissioning a Chinese company to install a telecommunications network Of course, Boris Johnson is right to make it clear he is not Donald Trump’s poodle.We don’t have to take notice of everything the Americans say, on defence, trade or anything .But when it comes to our closest ally warning us that it might not want to share intelligence with us in futurewe let a Chinese company build our G network, we very much do need to take notice.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP title: eu trade deal fishing rights
story: Eurocrats hardened their position on demanding continued access to our waters after Boris Johnson vowed not to extend the transition period beyond December .The EU said talks on fisheries will now have a “direct link” to thrashing out tarf and quota free trade on goods.Previously, the EU had stated access for its vessels would be secured “within the context of the overall economic partnership”.But Mr Johnson’s insistence the UK will quit the transition come what may at the end of this year has sparked concern in Brussels.Eurocrats believe only a “bare bones” trade deal on goods will be done by then and want to play hardball over fishing for maximum leverage.In a briefing to EU diplomats, Michel Barnier’s team said any deal on “reciprocal” access would be of “unprecedented scale and scope”.The pact would include agreements on quotas that European fishermen can land in our waters and a clause to protect their livelihoods.EU negotiators want to get it done by July  this year — the date by which the UK must say whether or not it plans to extend the transition.EU trade chief Phil Hogan has suggested fishing rights may be secured in a “trade-off” with the UK over market access for the City of London.Eurocrats argue access for EU boats cannot be separated from tarf-free terms for British fish products on EU markets.The PM has vowed to take back control of UK fishing waters when the transition period ends.Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen warned the PM he wont be able to “have his cake and eat it” in trade talks. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn meghan markle racism
story: The Labour boss spoke out after the Duchess was seen in Canada for the first time yesterday since announcing that she and Prince Harry would be stepping down as senior royals and wanted to spend more time in North America.The royals are currently thrashing out how the pair plan to become financially independent from the rest of the family - but Meghan has already flown back to Canada to be with baby Archie.Mr Corbyns spokesperson said this lunchtime: Jeremy has commented in the past in relation to Prince Harry and Meghan about press intrusion and its impact on people and their families.To use Prince Harrys words as well - the racial undertones in relation to how the media has approached Meghan.He [Corbyn] has spoken out about the concerns and obviously understands how press intrusion can have a negative impact on people and their private lives.Prince Harry accused the press of subjecting Meghan to a “wave of abuse and harassment” in November .And some commentators have claimed the pair are fleeing their roles to escape racism.However, Mr Corbyns spokesperson failed to give any examples of racist coverage.They said: Im not going to run through the full gamut of the coverage. He agrees with the broad sentiment which Harry has put forward.It comes just days after the Home Secretary, Priti Patel, said she did not believe the Duchess was a victim of media racism.The Home Secretary said Britain is a “great country full of opportunity” for people whatever their race or background.Ms Patel – Britain’s first female ethnic minority Home Secretary – said she does not think there has been any “racism”.She told BBC Radio  Live: “I am not in that category at all where I believe there has been racism.“I think we live in a great country, a great society, full of opportunity where people of every background can get on in le.”Askedthe media had been racist, she replied: “I don’t think so, no.“I certainly haven’t seen that through any debates or commentary or things of that nature.”Ms Patel, who was born in London to a Ugandan-Indian family, added: “As someone brought up in Britain, as someone from an immigrant background I think Britain is a country of tremendous opportunity.“Everyone has a perception of what they read in the press, but I certainly don’t see that.”

title: chopped into pieces iran
story: The chilling outburst by one of the Iranian regime’s most senior clerics has sparked concern for Rob Macaire’s safety.The ambassador has been at the centre of a diplomatic storm between Whitehall and Teheran since Saturday after he was arrested while attending a vigil for the downed Ukrainian airliner that killed  including four Brits.In a rabble rousing speech on Tuesday, Ayatollah Ahmad Alamolhoda told hundreds of followers: “Some say the UK Ambassador must be expelled.“Expelling the UK ambassador is the greatest act of kindness toward him. It would be a pardon.“No. The UK Ambassador must be chopped into pieces”.The cleric is supreme leader Ayatollah Khamenei’s representative in Mashhad, Iran’s second largest city.The senior diplomat was also labelled “persona non grata” by Iran’s judiciary and an effigy of the envoy was burned in Tehran by hardline protesters.The Foreign Office yesterday insisted Mr Macaire’sto London was long-planned and he will be going back to Tehran soon after meetings with the Foreign Secretary.In a bid to play down the blood curdling threats, an FCO spokesman said: “Ambassador Rob Macaire is ing to the UK today on a long-planned visit.“He will have a number of meetings while in the UK and this is very much business as usual. title: bed next to toilet flat camden rent london

title: harry wake up think what have i done liddle
story: But that should surely be a fairly simple matter. Harry and Meghan have said they wish to be “independent”. A lot of time has been spent working out how that independence can be achieved.Well, here’s the thing. I have a cunning plan for the Sussexes as to how they might be “independent”.What you need to do is get something called a “job”.If you get one of those they give you money which you can use to buy things — a house, some Pot Noodles, a Hot Wheels car racing set — anything, really, within reason.  Remarkable, isn’t it It probably wouldn’t pay for the £million Canadian mansion Meghan is holed up in right now — but they can always ponce a few freebies off their mega-rich friends.It might not quite cover the legal costs Meghan may incur from her upcoming court case. She’s suing a newspaper and her dad is set to testy AGAINST her.You have to say she has a knack, this lass, of getting on the wrong side of quite a few people.I think it’s fair to guess that the Royal Family are not entirely happy with her right now. So she’s hacked off her new family much as she’s hacked off her own one.It’s no huge surprise they’re both heading off to “Canada” .Meghan seems not to like the UK very much. She doesn’t spend much time in it and my suspicion is that the local people haven’t entirely taken to her.We had a bit of time for Harry, once. He seemed an amiably thick rugger-bugger with a mischievous sense of humour. Not any more, sadly.He seems to spend half of his time crying. And he also seems to have swallowed whole the air-headed, ultra-woke, touchy-feely drivel his we has imported from the United States.Still, we were happy to spend an extortionate sum doing up their “cottage” with the most expensive materials money could buy. And we were delighted to see photographs of young Archie — once we were allowed to by madam.For someone who dislikes the starchy formality of the Royal Family, Meghan displays quite a few airs and graces, doesn’t she Hates being photographed and gets her bullying minders to stop people taking snaps. Loves being photographed when she’s promoting herself or her vacuous ideas.But hey, they love each other and that’s the important thing.Let them move to Canada or LA, where they can jabber to each other about climate change and how everyone who doesn’t like her is racist, until the cows come home.But let them do it entirely independently. No money from the Duchy of Cornwall Estate. No royal stipend. No security staff paid for by the taxpayers, either here or there.Let them be truly independent, which is what they seem to wish for.Maybe they’ll find it liberating. Or maybe in a year or two Prince Harry will wake up and think: Crikey, what have I done.DO you remember when you first had a McDonald’s  I remember very well. I was  and had just come down to London from Middlesbrough.My girlfriend told me about these wonderful things called Big Macs. I tried one – couldn’t believe how delicious it was. So I bought another, and then another.Stood there, stuffing my fat face, eyes wide with delight.As the years go by, the pleasure diminishes a little – there’s nothing better than tasting something delicious for the first time.So lucky, lucky people of Rutland. The UK’s smallest county is to have its first ever McDonald’s.A lot of poncey residents opposed this happening because they said it would “lower the tone” of the county.Now the snobs can find out what they’ve been missing all these years.RIVETED with excitement by the Labour leadership contest  It’s a real humdinger, isn’t it I had rather hoped David Lammy would stand, just to give us all a laugh. Sadly, he’s not going to.Ultra Trot Clive Lewis has pulled out. But Emily Thornberry, above – Lady Nugee to you, you lowly serf – is through to the next round.If she wins it will be the final nail in the coffin of this once-great party.SO, Manchester City’s underperforming stars hired a whole bunch of Instagram “models” to attend a party at some posh place in Cheshire.Flew them over from Italy, shoved them in a hotel, Bob’s yer uncle.The wives and girlfriends of the players were not invited to this party. Lovely bunch, footballers, aren’t they And was all of this sanctioned by the supposedly progressive and right-on manager, Pep Guardiola “That was not what I meant, Senor Aguero, when I said you had to get in the box more often.” HERE is yet another Re-moaner head case for you. Liberal Democrat peer Lord Greaves.He has said he fears Britain will be reminiscent of Nazi Germany when we finally leave the European Union. Yup, that’s a sane and rational judgment, you bearded loon.He added: “People are crying when they go to sleep at night and when they wake up in the morning, and all they get from the unfeeling, hard-headed Tories is moans.“They are feeling a sense of loss which is akin to bereavement, and a grieving process has only just begun.“In these circumstances, triumphalistic behaviour, festivals of Brexit and all the rest will simply make things worse.”Who is crying  What bereavement process  What kind of drugs is Lord Greaves taking Let’s all go round to his gaff on January  with a few cans of Stella and try to cheer him up.A BRITISH mum is leading a fightback against the drive to make our children cretins.The unnamed woman went on Mumsnet to explain that she turns the house wi off at .pm every night.And tells her three kids – the oldest is  – to read a book instead. Good for her. Children seem to use the internet for just three things.Bitching about thots in their school. And sending snap-shots of their genitals to -year-old men who are pretending to be teenagers.THERE was a rather cheering plan to ring out the church bells across the land to mark our escape from the European Union at the end of the month.But a bunch of bishops have said we shouldn’t do that because the bells should only be used to summon the faithful to worship.With the greatest of respect, your reverend, b*****ks. You can tell it’s nothing to do with that by their comments.One said: “Two thirds of the population never voted for Brexit in the first place. It’s deeply isive to ring church bells for something like this.”Yeah, Bish – we have a habit in this country of only counting the votes of people who voted, you mimsy frock-wearing halfwit.Another said: “I think we should be ringing bells on February , not to celebrate Brexit but to call people together to pray for our nation at this critical time.”Ah, go shove your bells up your cassock, you miserable Remoaner God-bothering bores.A UKRAINIAN bloke woke up one morning to discover a large metal nut around his old fella.His we had placed it there during the night to stop him shagging other women. title: big ben must chime for brexit the miserabilists and pessimists cannot get their way
story: As Britain throws off the shackles of rule by the European Union, a new era of national freedom beckons.The arrival of British independence, after nearly half a century of Brussels domination, is a moment for profound celebration.And there could be no more appropriate way to mark this historic milestone than a series of chimes from the mighty bell that is Big Ben.For the landmark is a shining symbol of both British nationhood and our parliamentary democracy.Since its completion in , the clock tower synonymous with its famous bell has become a cultural icon, renowned across the world.At a height of ft, its majestic beauty epitomises the greatness of our country. The distinctive peal from its massive, .-ton bell is a part of the soundtrack of our public le.But sadly, it now seems likely that the advent of Brexit will be met by silence from Big Ben.If the parliamentary authorities have their way, no sound will echo from the clock tower on that momentous night.Since , the building has been undergoing a major renovation programme, including the installation of a lt, resurfacing of the dials, and restoration of the clock mechanism.According to the House of Commons Commission, which oversees the Westminster estate, the cost of interrupting this work to enable Big Ben to chime for Brexit would be more than £,.We are told this huge bill arises because of the need to install a temporary floor in the belfry to support the chiming equipment — as well as the impact of delays, for up to four weeks, in the renovation project.In the view of pessimistic officialdom, the whole idea of the Brexit chimes is just too expensive.As Sir Lindsay Hoyle, the new Speaker of the Commons, put it this week, “You are talking about £, a bong.”The arch-Remainers have, predictably, seized on the problem with glee.For them, the entire business is just like Brexit itself — a pointless, costly distraction.That negativity is shared by large parts of the civil service and Westminster establishment.Viewing Brexit with horror, they seek to prevent any inspirational commemoration of the event.So the supposed heavy costs give them the perfect excuse to do nothing, just as they used bureaucratic stalemate to thwart Brexit for years.Indeed, the Big Ben dficulty can be seen as ato Project Fear, once more, where dire financial warnings are deployed to frighten the public into inaction.But the British people did not give in to Project Fear , and they should not be cowered by more alarmism this time.The shrill negative voice of Remainers had dominated for too long.After the decisive General Election last month, that is the noise that should be hushed, not the chimes of Big Ben.Expressions of national pride are a force for benevolence and unity, as we witnessed in the recent cricket World Cup triumph.Despite all the Remainer gloom, there is a tremendous yearning to celebrate British-ness.That spirit can also be seen in the broad popular support for the idea of a new Festival of Britain, in , to extol the values of our nation.Once again, just as with their negativity over Big Ben, the pro-EU brigade sneered at the concept as nothing more than a Festival of Brexit, which could only enshrine entrenched isions.But in reality, just like the successful post-war Festival of Britain in , the  Festival could achieve the very opposite, by enabling us to reconnect with our identity, heritage and future.The same can be true of the Brexit chimes on January . It can be an occasion for joy and openness, not misery and fearfulness.Boris Johnson’s suggestion that the £, bill could be met by an appeal to the public is being scuppered by senior officials.In his usual inimitable style, Boris had asked for crowd-funding citizens to “bung a bob for a Big Ben bong”. There were signs the campaign could be taking off.The passionate Euro-sceptic MP Mark Francois pledged £,, while there was also speculation that millionaires such as Lord Ashcroft and Wetherspoon pub chain boss Tim Martin could make large donations.Officials yesterday said there was “no legal basis” for using public donations. So why shouldn’t the Government chip in  After all, the state is used to bankrolling exceptional national events, often at a far bigger cost.A reported £million went on Meghan and Harry’s wedding in .Most of that was swallowed up by security, but £, alone went on her bridal dress — which is not far off the cost of the Big Ben bongs.Similarly, the bill for the chimes is barely a quarter of the more than £million estimated to be spent on the official London fireworks display on New Year’s Eve.But before any money is handed over by the public or Treasury, the huge potential bill — £, to get the bell to chime, plus the £, cost of delays to the tower’s repair — must be challenged.In all kinds of major projects, because of weak management, contractors and consultants often expand the budgets for their own interests.We have seen that process with the HS rail link, now on course to cost over £billion, while even with the renovation of Big Ben the project’s bill has risen from an original £million to £million.On Tuesday night, one former project manager in Parliament said the estimate for the chimes had been absurdly inflated.“I cannot believe the costs you’re talking about,” he told LBC radio.The can-do, anti-establishment outlook ensured the victory of Brexit. With the same imagination and drive, the campaign for the Big Ben chimes can succeed.In fact, it could be the cue for a string of other celeb-rations across our land on January , like bonfires, fire-work displays or big screen-ings in city squares.But at the centre of it all has to be the Westminster clock tower. As Nigel Farage put it, “If Big Ben doesn’t sound, our country looks like a joke.”The miserabilists and pessimists must not get their way.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum knock and run teenagers bmw cheshire
story: Nicole Lyons, , screamed that she would slit their throats from an upstairs window before she ran the boys over in the village of Tarvin, Cheshire.One of the boys, aged , needed emergency surgery on his leg and spent six weeks in plaster, Cheshire Crown Court heard.His pal was left with back injuries from being hurled into the air from the force of the vehicle.Police found threatening draft messages on her Facebook account after arresting her, with one bragging that they had messed with the wrong house.The message read: Just so you know boys you messed with the wrong house.Do not come near my house again. You will have your throats ripped out, Ive seen your faces. I will be speaking to your mummys and daddys [sic].Lyons narrowly avoided a prison sentence after pleading guilty to grievous bodily harm, dangerous driving, assault and failing to stop and report an accident.Judge Simon Berkson told the mum-of-two who had a previous conviction for drink driving, the boys were innocent victims of you using the vehicle as a weapon.He added: They were playing a teenage game that has been played in this country for decades.This was a very dangerous piece of deliberate bad driving and you are fortunate the injuries are not worse than they were.The group of boys had been playing the prank, also known as knock down ginger, in the days leading up to the attack on January  last year.Myles Wilson, prosecuting, said the kids ran away after targeting Lyonss home.But  minutes later she borrowed her partners BMW  Series to go to the shop.On her way back she saw the kids at the entrance of the housing estate where she lived and she accelerated at them.All four wheels of the car mounted the pavement and she claimed the teenagers had been swearing at her and that she had driven slowly at them.However photos from the scene revealed tyre marks on the pavement contradicted that account.In a victim statement, the injured child said he still suffered from anxiety after the attack.Another said that he wasnt able to get Lyonss angry face and noise of the engine out of his head.Lyons, who apologised to the boys as she left the dock, was given  months in jail, suspended for  months and a two-year driving ban.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince harry megxit rugby world cup
story: The Duke of Sussex dodged questions over his future amid the royal crisis as he appeared at the Rugby League World Cup draw.But some nerves seemed to creep in earlier despite his brave face as he anxiously fiddled with his wedding ring.Harry has delayed a reunion with Meghan and baby Archie in Canada and will be staying in the UK until next week to sort the couples royal exit fallout.The engagement today could potentially be his final public duty as a senior royal as it is not clear what his meetings next week are.Harry - patron of the Rugby Football League - is meeting representatives of the  nations taking part while watching local kids playing rugby in the palace gardens.He joked as he posed up with the budding rugby stars, telling them: Look after the grass though yeah  Otherwise Ill get in trouble.The prince drew teams for the World Cup next year and also host the  draw from the palace for the mens, womens and wheelchair tournaments.Harry appeared happy as he went back to the day job and chatted with RLWs chief executive officer Jon Dutton and its non-executive director Stuart Cain.Harry was joined by rugby legend Jason Robinson and Dame Katherine Grainger, chair of UK Sport, as he pulled the first ball to Englands mens team would be playing Samoa in their opening game.He had been asked about impact of sport on peoples lives and described it as having the power to save lives while in the palace throne room.The duke answered: I think, from my perspective, certainly the experience that Ive had in my younger years but also through Invictus, and all of the sporting events that Im lucky enough to be able to go to or watch, the impact that it has, especially on young people, but the impact it has on the iniduals playing with the community as a whole is remarkable.Not only do I continue to see sport actually changing lives, but its saving lives as well, so I think for me and ... everybody in this room, whether its rugby league, or sports in general ... it needs to be in everybodys lepossible.Australia rugby representative and host of the Channel  satirical show The Last Leg, Adam Hills, said the prince showed his duty and commitment despite everything  thats going on in his le.It comes after Harry earlier urged men suffering from mental health issues to not just grin and bear it as he launched a Mental Fitness Charter.The charter is aimed at training players, officials and volunteers to look after their own mental health and the mental health of those around them.He said: It is not just about being physically fit but more importantly mentally strong.The perception of rugby league is that you need to be tough. You cant show your feelings, you need to grin and bear it.But something like the Mental Fitness Charter will help us make real progress in getting rid of the stigma associated with mental illness.It has been a turbulent week for Harry, who supposed to be joining his we at their £million Canada hideaway after sensationally revealing they were working towards becoming financially independent.Instead, he has been forced to stay in the UK after triggering a major crisis for the monarchy.And he last night broke his silence on the Sussex Royal Instagram page to reveal the location of the  Invictus Games would be in Dusseldorf.Harry said: I hope everyone in Germany is ready for what will be an incredible week of sport.I have no doubt that the German public will get right behind these games and that every single competitor can expect a warm welcome and an amazing atmosphere.He also confirmed  countries joining in for the  games, adding: The story continues.Meghan meanwhile has been snapped looking relaxed as she visited another womens charity in Vancouver.The Duchess of Sussex was pictured chatting with women at Justice For Girls - a charity promoting an end to violence and racism against teenage girls living in poverty.She was seen for the first time since announcing she and Harry want to quit royal le as she boarded a seaplane from Vancouver Island to Vancouver to carry out the charity visits on Tuesday.There was no sign of nine-month-old son Archie, who was believed to have been left with a nanny.She was escorted to the plane by a bodyguard. An airport source said: “She didn’t have to sit and wait with other passengers inside the terminal.”It came after Harry was locked in crisis talks with the Queen, Prince Charles and Prince William over their future.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex got their way at the summit — but the Queen made it plain she is deeply upset they are quitting.After the Sandringham talks, Her Majesty released a statement saying the couple will be allowed to step down from their duties and spend time in Canada.But she said: “Although we would have preferred them to remain full-time working members of the Royal Family, we respect and understand their wish to live a more independent le.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy bamber gets birthday cards from fans
story: The White House Farm killer receives a bulging bag of letters each day from his army of supporters who also send cash to his prison bank account.Bamber, who was jailed in  for the slaughter of his parents, his sister and her six-year-old twin sons, can then spend the funds on toiletries and treats from catalogues or buy snacks in the prison canteen.The killer is also allowed to reply to emails that are sent to top security Wakefield prison in West Yorkshire – but does not have internet access.On a website set up to trumpet his alleged innocence, supporters are told: “If you write to Jeremy and would like a reply to your letter please enclose an SAE or send stamps, which helps Jeremy to keep in touch with the outside. You can include more than one SAE in each letteryou wish.“Owing to the volume of mail sent to Jeremy each day it can take a while for you to receive a response so please allow  weeks before writing again or contacting us.“All mail is censored by the prison so please do not send letters longer than two sides of A paper . You must include your name and address or Jeremy will not be able to receive your correspondence stamps.”His fans also provided payment details so cash can be sent directly into his prison account via a government website.And the site adds: “You can send photographs, drawings, paintings, cards, print outs from the internet or extracts from books, magazines or news articles, writing pads and envelopes but no other stationery including writing pads bound with wire.Do not send cards with organic or other material stuck on them, glitter, sticky pads or concealed sections.“You cannot send cards with any concealed , bits stuck on including card, paper, jewels, fabric, organic material.”Supporters are also told: “Or you can email Jeremy using the emailaprisoner service, but note that Jeremy cannot directly reply using email, as he does not have internet access, however the service now allows Jeremy to write a response which can be emailed bythrough the prison censor.”Bamber was jailed for le with no possibility of parole for the shooting of his family in August , in the parents farmhouse in Essex,  which came to be known as the White House Farm murders.The prosecution was able to persuade the jury that, after committing the murders to secure a large inheritance, Bamber had placed the gun in the hands of his -year-old sister Sheila Caffell, who had been diagnosed with schizophrenia, to make the scene appear to be a murder–suicide.The horric murders have since been turned into an ITV drama called White House Farm, starring Freddie Fox as Bamber.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour urge brexit backing working class northerners to join party now to vote for new leader
story: Party chairman Ian Lavery and Shadow Cabinet Office Minister Jon Trickett made the demand after claiming the party had been taken over by remain-supporting metropolitan elite members.Membership can cost as little as £ a year, but registered supporters can also vote in the leadership by paying £.In an attempt to stop the millionaire lawyer in his tracks, they have now issued a call to arms.Writing in the Mirror, they said: “When Labour wins, it is because a coalition of working and middle class people believe in our party to make Britain a better place.“However our membership is now disproportionately one that voted to Remain in the referendum and drawn from the South, mainly from metropolitan areas and from the middle classes.“To win again the coalition of working and middle class people within our own party must be rebalanced.“That is why we are calling for Labour supporters from working class backgrounds and from the North to join the party by January  and have their say in the upcoming leadership election.”Sir Keir Starmer-  per centJess Phillips-  per centLisa Nandy-  per centEmily Thornberry  per centSir Keir Starmer: The former director of public prosecutions was elected in Holborn and St Pancras in , and is a staunch remainer who has been accused of being too middle-class.Rebecca Long-Bailey: The shadow energy secretary has been labelled as continuity Corbyn, and has made clear she will keep going with the partys radical agenda.Lisa Nandy: A former charity worker, the Wigan MP has repeatedly bashed the Labour leadership, and most recently gone viral with a flurry of memes about towns.Jess Phillips: The Birmingham Yardley MP is a committed campaigner on domestic abuse, but has irritated members by questioning Mr Corbyns leadership.Emily Thornberry: The Islington South and Finsbury MP was considered close to her constituency neighbour, only to be shunted aside after calling for a second referendumMr Lavery has already voiced his support for far-left contender Rebecca Long-Bailey, while Mr Trickett is also believed to support her.Emily Thornberry,  Lisa Nandy and Jess Phillips are also vying for the top job.Yesterday Ms Nandy turned on the current Labour leader, accusing him of failing on Russia over the Salisbury terror attack.She said: We stood with the Russian government, and not with the people it oppresses, who suffer poverty and discrimination. We failed the test of solidarity.

title: bbc bosses asking jobseekers what their parents do for a living in bonkers application
story: Wannabe employees are also being asked what qualications their mum and dad have - and what school they attended.As well as providing their own background, applicants have to spend hours filling in pages of info on their families.In a bizarre and extremely y form, applicants are also askedtheir parents or s have a degree, or equivalent, and which type of school they went to.Options range from a state-run, non-selective school to an independent or fee-paying school.The BBC asks all potential employees to fill out the -page online form when applying for work at its London-based headquarters.As part of the mandatory questions, jobseekers must saytheir parents had a modern professional occupation – such as a teacher or nurse. Otherwise they must statethey were ever senior managers or administrators or unemployed.Anyone applying for a job at the Beeb has the option of ticking a prefer not to say box. But, an answer is required to go on with the application.Officials at the Corporation say they’re aiming to make the company more erse.Its not the first time the Corporation has been blasted over its job applications.In , the Beeb was slammed for excluding white people from applying for a trainee journalism role.The ad for a trainee-scheme at Newsbeat, the BBCs current affairs outlet for - year olds, said: This traineeship is only open to candidates from a black, Asian or non-white ethnic minority background.And in  it was mocked for a jargon-filled job ad searching for a new Head of Change.The bizarre advert included the word change  times and left senior execs startled by the baffling jargon.Top bosses worked with an organisation called the Bridge Group for advice on the latest application process. The consultants told them parental occupation is a strong indicator of a persons background and status in society.In , BBC managers were sent on compulsory cultural awareness courses. Quotas were also introduced to make sure there’s at least one black, Asian or minority ethniccandidate on the shortlist for senior jobs.A BBC spokesman said: Its important the BBC represents the whole of the UK, so to help improve socio-economic ersity we are asking applicants about their background.While it has no impact on the success of a job application and is not visible to the person hiring, collating this data is the first step in ensuring the BBC is recruiting from as wide a group of people as possible.

title: brits name sir david attenborough as their dream prime minister
story: A poll of , adults has revealed who they would really like to see running the country.The popular naturalist beat close rivals Stephen Fry and Richard Branson to be named the person who should have moved into  Downing Street.His calming tones, love for the environment and popularity with people of all ages saw him win more than a fth of the vote.Ant and Dec - doing the job together - also featured in the top  list, along with JK Rowling, Adele and Stormzy.The study, commissioned by Sky to launch its new action-packed political drama, COBRA, also saw England football manager Gareth Southgate and actress Helen Mirren among the top choices.Airing on Sky One today , COBRA is set in the heart of government during a time of national crisis and stars Robert Carlyle as Prime Minister, Robert Sutherland, and Victoria Hamilton as his Chief of Staff, Anna Marshall, who must contend with impossible political decisions as they deal with a national emergency that threatens the very stability of the UK.A spokesperson for Sky said: “As a much loved and trusted figure, its not a surprise that David Attenborough topped the poll for PM.“As we have Robert Carlyle playing the Prime Minister in our new series COBRA we thought it would be fun to find out which celebrities the public thought would be best running the country.”Jeremy Clarkson came fourth in the poll, followed by Hugh Grant, who played a popular Prime Minister in  classic Love Actually.Piers Morgan, Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp and Harry Potter star Emma Watson were also among the popular candidates for the top job.But Mary Berry won the battle of the Great British Bake Off, with the former judge of the TV show coming in above her successor Pru Leith.The study also found nearly half of the population reckon they themselves could do better jobs in Government than those currently holding the roles.And four in  think their chosen celebrities would be more trustworthy than the real-le politicians in power.One in five of those polled, via OnePoll, even admitted to being more likely to vote a celebrity into office during an election than the standing politicians.Sky original drama COBRA launches today,  January, on Sky One and NOW TV.

title: elephant buddhist temple sri lanka
story: Myan Prince was filmed lying helplessly on its side as the man whips him with a sharp stick at a Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka.The footage shows the -year-old elephants legs chained to two trees surrounding the murky pool at Bellanwila Temple, just south of the capital, Colombo.It appears they are trying to wash Myan Princes legs, leading to outraged activists sharing many videos of the elephant in distress.In another upsetting video, Myan Prince is heard howling as he splashes in the pool while a keeper can be heard shouting and whipping him.In one image, a man is seen posing on top of the elephant as it stays chained to the tree.In February , the elephant was blamed by the Sri Lankan press for killing an elderly monk at the temple.It was first reported that Myan Prince pushed the -year-old to the ground during his breakfast feed.The temple later denied the attack and said the monk fell and suffered a heart attack, the Sri Lankan Observer reported at the time.Maneesha Arachchige, an activist from Rally for Animal Rights and Environment, visited the temple yesterday and said she fears for Myan Princes le.She told : We are very concerned for the welfare of Myan Prince.He seems to be being beaten on a regular basis and the temple seems unconcerned.If action is not taken quickly we fear for the safety of those around the elephant as well as Myan Prince’s safety and wellbeing.Elephants are considered sacred animals in Sri Lanka and are used for religious ceremonies.In September, an elephant named Tikiri died after she was forced to march for miles in a Bhuddist festival in the country.Pictures of the -year-old female elephant shocked the world after he was photographed with protruding ribs.Last year we reported on a disturbing video showing an elephant that collapsed and died after being forced to carry tourists in Sri Lanka.Animal rights campaigners said the -year-old elephant, named Kanakota, died of exhaustion after carrying holidaymakers on safari.The elephant was pictured covered in a blanket as distressed locals in Sigiriya, central Sri Lanka looked on after he had lay down and died.Kanakota had reportedly already title: putin rule stalin changes parliament russia
story: The Russian leader, , yesterday revealed sweeping changes to the country’s constitution resulting in his entire government resigning.The shock move is ostensibly designed to give more power to the parliament in Moscow while weakening the presidency.However, it is feared the move will create a powerful new position for Putin to step into once his current term as president ends in .Expert Mark Almond, director of the Crisis Research Institute in Oxford, believes the move is the former KGB spy attempting to weaken his successor while he continues to pull the strings from the shadows.In the Daily Mail, he writes: “By the time his current term ends in , with him in his early s, Putin will then in all likelihood take up the role of the grand old man – perhaps the godfather is a more fitting title – of Russian politics.“But make no mistake, he will still be all-powerful, the ultimate back seat driver.“There are precedents for rulers being seen to step back, but continuing to pull strings from behind the scenes.”Almond compares Putin’s future role to that of feared Soviet leader Joseph Stalin who ruled with “an iron fist” until he died in .He also points out that communist China in the s had a godfather-style leader in Deng Xiaoping and that Kazakhstan’s former President Nursultan Nazarbayev, only last year, stepped down to take up a new position as head of a “guiding” security council.And public opinion of Putin, at least in Moscow, appears to be high.BBC Radio ’s The Today programme spoke to commuters in the Russian capital and noted that most were enthusiastically supportive of the strongman remaining in power.One woman said: “He’s the best president we’ve ever had.“I don’t mind eating turnips and grass – Putin is right to spend our money on building up our defences.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple with 31 year age gap got engaged just four weeks after first date insist its true love
story: Vianca has lashed out at naysayers who claim shes only with her -year-old fiancé Antonio for his money.First and foremost Tonys not a millionaire, he likes good things and yes he does like to spoil me. And I do ask for it, she said.Antonio, who works as a general contractor at a firm, often spoils his fiancé with designer goods and lavish international vacations.But the -year-old, who works as a full-time nanny for disabled kids, insists that her intentions of marrying Tony are pure.I never grew up knowing that material things arent it, and when I met Tony he was honest and told me he wasnt rich, she claims.I dont need his money at all. What Im interested in is him and getting to know him.The lovebirds met through a mutual friend in March  and had their first date a month later.It was Antonios voice that captivated her, Vianca says, and she begged her friend to make the introduction.When I saw him, it was definitely love at first sight, she gushed.Their intense chemistry quickly morphed into a full-blown romance, with the couple spending nearly every day with each other.Four weeks later, Tony proposed to Vianca on a restaurant date, and she happily accepted.From Viancas perspective, money isnt everything - she often eschews designer goods to shop at Walmart.Shes adamant that their love is real - not a sugar baby arrangement.I am no sugar baby. But like I said, Tony does buy good things.Despite the challenges that come with an age-gap relationship, she says dating an older, more mature person has opened her eyes to new things and provides a sense of security and protection she never had.Vianca, who was adopted at a young age, says she looks up to her fiancé as a positive role model and considers him her rock.There are unique benefits, I say that the love and support you get from a person with maturity is very special.I went from having nothing to having a positive role model to help me become better than the person I was.Having grown up with a silver spoon in his mouth, Antonio said Vianca has taught him how to appreciate the simple things in le.My le has changed in huge ways, I came from having everything in le whereas Vianca taught me that the big things in le dont matter, he said.She is such a strong independent woman and shes taught me...that having big things dont define happiness. Its the little things that count.The couple is now planning their wedding - they plan to say I do in Puerto Rico next year, and hope to start a family soon.They stress that age is just a number and insist that love and connection are the keys to a successful relationship.We want people to understand that age is nothing but another, explained Vianca.If its destined to be with someone young and theres a love connection it shouldnt have to matter, its your heart.GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mexican meghan markle lookalike begs leave her alone
story: Linda Martinez, , from Mexico first saw Meghan Markle as her Rachel Zane alter-ego in American hit series, Suits.She soon became a fan of her sophisticated dress sense and was in awe of her own personal backstory and humanitarian work.Ever since Prince Harry and Meghan announced they were dating in , Linda, who is also an avid royal watcher, has followed the Duchess of Sussexs wardrobe choices with a close eye.She said: “I was a Meghan fan because of Suits but when I did my research and I found out about her family and work, and all the things she has done to get what she has and where she is today, I started to admire her a lot and wanted to be like her.“I wanted to be like her as a human being, she’s an empowered woman and has the most incredible style.Linda has now copied around  of the Duchess’ better-known looks.With the ‘Megxit’ crisis rolling on, Ms Martinez still believes the Duchess is a strong role model to young people.She said: “I guess is not easy for her [Meghan] to be there in the royal family with all the prejudices in society and classy people who maybe would only accept royals before.“Right now, we see her living a great le, but we don’t know all the things she has had to change or accept to get that. I admire her strength and her kindness with people and that she is true to herself through it all.”Ms Martinez is supportive of the royal couple’s decision to step down as senior members of the royal family.She said: “I think they [Meghan and Harry] have all the right to decide what the best is for their family, as long as they are happy. They deserve to enjoy their le, to have their space and to feel safe. I totally support their decision.“To me, she is a super strong, independent, resilient, feminist. An empowered woman who has used her  to support others. That is what I admire about her.Ms Martinezs support for the Sussexs comes after Prince Harry was locked in crisis talks with the Queen, Prince Charles and Prince William over his familys future.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex got their way at the summit — but the Queen made it plain she is deeply upset they are quitting.After the Sandringham talks, Her Majesty released a statement saying the couple will be allowed to step down from their duties and spend time in Canada.But she said: “Although we would have preferred them to remain full-time working members of the Royal Family, we respect and understand their wish to live a more independent le.”

title: jeremy corbyn bags one of parliaments best offices from red wall mp who lost seat
story: They are furious because the office belonged to popular Labour veteran Vernon Coaker - one of the MPs who lost their seats in the demolition of the Red Wall in the midlands and the north.One Labour MP blasted: Its added insult to injury because hes jumping into the grave of one of the partys last remaining great MPs - and Corbyn is the reason hes gone.The office is viewed by MPs as one of the best on the estate because it is a penthouse suite overlooking Parliament Square.Mr Corbyn has already began moving into the new office despite not stepping down as Labour leader until April .The office is much bigger and better located than his current one, which is located at the edge of the Parliamentary estate.It sits above the atrium of Parliaments Portcullis House, the modern part of the estate where many MPs meet for lunch, coffee and meetings.Mr Corbyns spokesperson declined to comment.

The government admitted today that thousands had to wait until after death to be refunded Employment and Support Allowancein a blunder dating back almost decade. Labour branded the figures a national scandal. An error meant thousands of claimants were awarded too little ESA - worth up to £. a week - when they moved over from old-style incapacity benefit since . For two years, the Department for Work and Pensionshas been working through , cases to check who was short-changed. Official figures now show , people were repaid an average of £, each - totalling £m in refunds. But , of those people have already died. The money, totalling £m or £, a head, goes to their next of kin. Shadow Minister for Disabled People Marsha De Cordova said: “It is a national scandal that a decade of delay has meant that , ill and disabled people have died before receiving the money that they were owed as a result of ESA underpayments. “The government must now speedily complete the remaining reassessments for the thousands of people still waiting so that everyone who has lost out receives payment as quickly as possible.The Conservatives have consistently failed sick and disabled people. The continued delay in righting this wrong is disgraceful.”

The mum-of-two was breastfeeding her baby when she was forced to run into the garden to rescue her dog and chase off the driver. Eilis, , has since received a box full of food treats from Amazon which came with the message: Not in the dog house. The delivery driver, who is understood to have become irritated by the presence of the dog, has been fired, according to the mum. Referring to a bone disorder which affects her petaposs hips, she added:having to take him to the vets as he already has Perthaposs disease and is seriously limping from this attack. title: dog walker accused losing tamworth
story: NewsDog walker accused of losing Tamworth Five dogs to face prosecutionLouise Lawford had been looking after the pooches for three owners when she claimed they suddenly bolted after been spooked by a gun shot in the woodsShareByMark CardwellKelly-Ann Mills:,  JAN NewsOne of the missing dogs " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA professional dog walker accused of losing several pets who became known as the Tamworth Five will face prosecution for animal welfare offences, it has emerged. Louise Lawford had been looking after the pooches for three owners when she claimed they suddenly bolted after been spooked by a gun shot. The dogs disappeared while being walked in Hopwas Woods, near Tamworth, Stafforshire, on June  last year. Hundreds of people joined a search to track down Pablo, Maggie, Charlie, Ralph and Jack but they were never found. Suspicious owners said they contacted police after Lawford, , stopped taking their calls.  Police said following an investigation there was insufficient evidence to charge her with theft. However, it emerged today that Lawford will be hauled before a court after Birmingham City Council accused of a string of animal welfare offences. Lawford, who ran Pawford Paws in Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands, will appear before Birmingham Magistratesapos Court next Thursday.She is accused of nine animal welfare offences, including five counts of undertaking group walks without insuring each dog had been vaccinated, allowing dogs off the lead without written consent and failing to contact the owners or dog warden immediately when dogs were lost.She also faces three counts of breaching conditions of the licence to operate a business providing home boarding for dogs and a charge of failing to provide veterinary treatment for a skin infection for a dog.The city council also confirmed Lawford, of Erdington, Birmingham, had her dog boarding licence revoked on June . One owner Becky Parsons, , of Erdington, Birmingham lost Pablo the pug and Maggie the Jack Russell and described it as her worst nightmare.She said at the time: I had given my dogs over Louise to look after while I was on holiday.As soon as I got back I looked myself and I couldnapost find them. My heart is broken.The dogs have died. Iaposm in bits. Maggie and Pablo were my best friends. My heart just sunk when I found out. All of this hope that I had just gone.I lost my dad, nan, granddad and partner in a short space of time and the dogs were my comfort. They were my companions that kept me going, they gave me a purpose to carry and now thataposs been taken away.Another owner April Lock, , of Streetly, West Midlands, left dogs Charlie and Ralph in Louiseaposs care while he went to Spain. Speaking at the time of their disappearance, she said: I was told the same tale as Becky that they had run off after a loud bang in the woods but I donapost believe that.I have no clue where my dogs have gone, just that they were supposedly last seen in Hopwas Woods. It makes no sense.Iaposve had both dogs since they were eight weeks old. Charlieaposs vision is blurry, heaposs partially blind.Heaposs a greedy dog but can get frustrated because of his sight but heaposs very laid back and chilled.Ralph would be terried right now, I know it. Iaposm at my wits end over this and just want to know whats happened to my dogs. Itaposs weird.

story: NewsopinionIm finally marrying my superhero who has been my rock while I battle cancerMum, cancer fighter andcolumnist Roisin Pelan is marrying her partner - and she cant waitShareByRoisin Pelan:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionRoisin is tying the knot with her partner, Michael " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Amen. But now, we save, we diet, we plan. It’s bloody hard work. Now we’re parents of two . We’re skintand we’re trying to balance chemo cancer children and no financial help from the government. I’m not entitled to adoption pay because I haven’t earned enough in the last year . The only financial help our good old government has ever given us started last year which was a whopping £ per week. I’m due for my PIPS assessment again soon and the idea of it is making me ill. Last time, I was asked questions along the lines of aposdo you need someone to help you to wipe after you’ve been to the toiletapos. Just to make you feel all the more degraded. The bastards. I went for a job interview last week . Although I desperately need the job, I’m so worried about how I’m going to juggle it all too - chemo, children, saving for a wedding, bills, appointments, the school run, childcare etc and on top of this, the stress of the cancer coming back. I was copied into a letter this week from my wonderful consultant who is helping with my PIPS assessment. I saw the words incurable metastatic breast cancer and I felt sick. It’s just feeling too much at the mo. There are more pressures but I can’t talk about those just yet but they are having such a big impact on us. All I can say is roll on three months time. Sigh. Aaanyway, bloody hell, enough of all that negativity. Here I am, LIVING my le, planning a wedding and looking for jobs. I am bloody LUCKY! I know people who would give anything to have the secondchances I’ve been given. I’m testing out lots of products to use for our wedding. Tans, hair extensions because I want long hair for the big day. In the meantime, someone recommended Waterman’s for helping with hairgrowth. I started using it last week so I’ll let you know how I get on with it and anything I can get my hands on to help firm up my ageing skin . I read somewhere that chemotherapy ages you at twice the rate of a ‘normal’ person. So by rights, I’m . I’ve got my hands on some deeeelicious Coco  Eve tan and OMG I swear to you, I have never smelt anything so absolutely ine. I’m trying it out this week because tomorrow I’m trying on a dress that I’m hoping will be THE ONE. I’ve had a nightmare with the dress, which I won’t bore you with but I’m hoping - thanks to the power of Instagram that I’ve got quite a few options. I’ll be letting you all know what my favourite products are so keep your eyes peeled. And I was even featured in Cheshire Bride this month.

story: NewsSepsis rates in Britain among worst in Europe as infection kills , a yearA new study has found the UK has worse rates of killer sepsis infections than Kazakhstan and Iran as campaigners warn pressures facing the NHS is leaving patients at riskShareByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSepsis is a killer infection that is costing too many Brits their lives " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDeadly sepsis infection rates in Britain are some of the worst in Europe leading to around , deaths every year. A shock report in the respected Lancet journal reveals the UK fared worse than all EU nations apart from Portugal and the Ukraine. The study found we had more cases per , of the population than Vietnam, Kazakhstan and Iran. Experts warn infections are more likely as record numbers of NHS patients are having to be cared for in corridors. UK sepsis rates were th worst out of  nations, compared to Romania in th place, Germany in th, Ireland in th and Iceland in th. The analysis suggests that the horrying infection claimed , lives here in . Dr Ron Daniels, chief executive of the UK Sepsis Trust, said: “This is an enormously prevalent and deadly condition that we need to take more seriously. “With increasing stress on healthcare systems in which patients might be cared for in corridors away from the most hygienic clinical areas, then the risk of sepsis increases. “As the NHS is increasingly under pressure to discharge patients then people first develop symptoms when they are at home. “This data confirms sepsis is as common as heart attacks and more deadly than any cancer.” AEs have faced their worst month on record with more than , patients facing  hour trolley waits in Decembner.  Almost , sick patients faced waiting more than four hours from a decision to admit to eventually being given a ward bed over Christmas. Both are the worst since records began. Four in every five sepsis develop in patients outside of hospitals. If often develops after patients have been discharged following surgery. Campaigners are demanding that the NHS starts routinely recording sepsis deaths as current data on lives lost is based on estimates. Infections are often triggered by hospital superbugs. The international review found there was an estimated , UK cases of sepsis over the year, or  cases per , of the population. Globally it has become a bigger killer than cancer. The study estimated there are more than double the number of deaths than previously thought, many in developing countries. Their Global Burden Of Disease Reporton sepsis estimates there were . million cases in , and  million deaths, across  countries and territories. This equates to just under a fthof all global deaths that year. ■ Sepsis affects , people in the UK and kills , per year. That’s more than bowel, breast and prostate cancer and road accidents combined. ■ Sepsis is the body’s often deadly response to an infection. ■ Initially, it can look like flu or a chest infection, but it can swtly get serious. ■ Seek medical help urgentlyyou develop any one of the following… – are lethargic or dficult to wake – feel abnormally cold to touch – the skin looks mottled, bluish or pale – are breathing very fast – have a rash that does not fade when you press it – have a fit or convulsion The UK was ranked  out of the  countries listed by their estimated death rates from highest to lowest, with an estimated . deaths per , people. Study author Dr Mohsen Naghavi, of Washington University, said: “We are alarmed to find sepsis deaths are much higher than previously estimated, especially as the condition is both preventable and treatable. “We need renewed focus on sepsis prevention among newborns and on tackling antimicrobial resistance, an important driver of the condition.” The researchers acknowledge their estimates may be conservative, due to reliance on death certicates which may not explicitly list sepsis as a contributing factor. The  countries with the highest death rates were all in Africa, with the Central African Republic leading the survey. On the other end of the scale, those with the lowest death rates were mainly Middle Eastern and wealthier countries. What is sepsis  Sepsis is a form of blood poisoning when the immune system overreacts to an infection or injury. It can result in organ failure and death and often affects babies. Patients who survive often have to have limbs amputated. How do you get it  Sepsis can arise as a consequence of any infection but most commonly following pneumonia, water infections, bites, cuts or burns.

Their historical decision - which they reportedly didnapost consult the rest of The Firm on - has sent shockwaves through the Palace and resulted in a number of highly unusual statements. But they are not the first Royals to make the radical decision to change their lives forever, and they could look to Swedenaposs Princess Madeleine as they start to plan their future. The mum-of-three is the daughter of the King of Sweden King Carl XVI Gustaf and grew up third in line to the throne, under her older sister Crown Princess Victoria.The sisters are two of the most stylish royals in Europe , but they lead very, very dferent lives after Madeleine stepped back from her duties to live in New York.She moved to America to mend a broken heart after breaking up with her lawyer fiance Jonas Bergström. Despite Madeleineaposs position in the line of succession, O’Neill didnapost get a title when he joined the family.
